description.narrative: Education providers, parents and communities have improved knowledge and skills to contribute to quality learning in inclusive safe and protective school environments, which contributes to Cross-Sectoral Communication For Development, Equitable Access To Quality Education, Equitable Access To Quality Education (Covid), Learning Outcomes, Learning Outcomes (Covid), Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children, Skills Development, Skills Development (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, United Nations Working Together. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2021, more children have access to early stimulation and quality basic education and learning in inclusive and safe school environments.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Education providers, parents and communities have improved knowledge and skills to contribute to quality learning in inclusive safe and protective school environments

description.narrative:
Improvements of elements of quality education were made including the support to inclusive and protective school environments; enhancing school leadership and governance; building the capacity of teachers and school partners; and improving life-skills of children and adolescents.
Parent-Teacher Associations (PTAs) in a total of 596 schools, which represents 238% of the annual target, were established and trained on how to develop school improvement plans that address quality learning, equity and protective school environments. These plans were implemented in schools using school grants. Moreover,4,689 primary school teachers (44% women) benefitted from in-service teacher trainings, achieving 78.5% of the annual target. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:31/12/2019
